dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Anyway... Her chipper Brooklyn/Jersey accent rings out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie makes her way through the store, happy and confuse

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Today I went across the street to the Apple store and got one of the new iPhones with the 64 gigabytes cause I wasn't sure if I should get the 16s or the 64s but the 64s looked good so there you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie has breakfast with her iPhone.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The genius bartender showed me how to make things bigger but I already forgot. God, my eyesight is so shot. But I got on the Safari before and I looked up The Palazzo and it said they filmed “The Hills" here for two seasons. Isn't that neat? -- Marnie happily weaves through The Grove’s morning crow

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And they used to do the Extra program at The Grove every day with Mario Lopez. He seems nice. -- Marnie stands shyly at the fountain, watching the chi play nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I swear I could stand there and watch that fountain for hours. Today they played “Come Fly With Me" and I almost started crying thinking about Daddy. But I didn't cause basically, I feel great. -- Marnie buys a Wetzel Pretzel.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's like living on Main Street in Disneyland. Every day is sunny and I wake up and I think, “Thank you, Joey, for making it possible.” -- The trolley man rings the bell, Marnie scuttles out of way, packages from Crate & Barrel in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I swear, if I get hit by that trolley, I'll die happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie puts pillows, still tagged, on her small couch.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And just wait ‘til you see my apartment. -- Marnie has a cup of decaf at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have a balcony that's far enough from other peoples' balconies so nobody could jump down from the roof or whatever... -- Marnie looks off her small balcony, eyeing, suspicious

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I have a parking spot right next to the elevator so I can just run right in there. -- Underground, Marnie sprints from her Toyota toward the elevator, bags in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I got everything shipped out from Jersey. All my artwork... -- Marnie hangs up a local-artist painting of Kermit the playing guitar in the woods.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The doll I had made of you... -- Marnie sets out a HANDMADE DOLL replicated to look lik her DAUGHTER as a little kid, next to a matching photo.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And of course the pictures of me and Daddy on our honeymoon. -- She slides a photo in her mirror. A YOUNGER MARNIE and her HANDSOME ITALIAN HUSBAND when he was alive.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: God, I can't believe I smoked back then. I hope you're not still smoking. It's really bad for you. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- MORNING 5 Marnie awkwardly drives up Laurel Canyon, holding her iPh on speaker.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Anyway... call me back. Love you. She hangs up. Then turns up her Beyonce CD, humming along

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- SAME TIME 6 LORI (30s) lies face down in bed, a cell phone buzzing in outstretched hand. She looks at it. CLOSE on: MA VOICEMAIL (5) Lori closes her eyes again. Almost immediately, the doorb RINGS. She sits up. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER 7 Lori opens the door to see Marnie holding up a brown bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought bagels.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: You should've called.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: But I didn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sure you were busy. Marnie hugs Lori, then gives her the bag. Lori follows he inside the small, neglected house.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Say hi to your grand-dogs. TWO MUTTS jump and sniff at Marnie. She pets them with th back of her hand, clearly uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Hi, doggies. Hello. Marnie shuts the front door, leaving the dogs outside.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: (looking in bag) Six bagels. All salt.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: They're the best kind. (seeing something) Oh Lor, you let Daddy’s bonsai die? Marnie goes to the bonsai, trying to spruce it back to li

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Yeah... Sorry, Mom... I tried. They're like crazy delicate. It was... crazy. Marnie tsks sadly, then whispers to Heaven:

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Joey.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: See, this is why I asked you not to put me in charge. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can’t just give someone a man’s bonsai and orchid and put all this pressure on them.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You let the orchid die too?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Yes “I let it die”. I watered it every day.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Lor, you’re not supposed to water it every day.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Well, I watered it the right amount, okay? Plants die. It’sa part of plant life. Please don’t make me feel any more bad about it.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Alright, forget it. Lori puts a bagel in the toaster. Marnie looks through a pile of Lori’s mail and sees an INVITATION.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Emily's baby shower.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Do you get to bring somebody?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Why? I probably won’t go.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Cause I’1ll have to get all dressed up... And it’s gonna be like everyone I know there... Lori disappears into a cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I thought you stopped smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding in smoke) Cigarettes. (exhaling) You said this was better.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I said it was okay after your father died when your stomach hurt.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Well, it’s after my father died. And my stomach hurts. Lori disappears into the cabinet again.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, have you heard from Jacob? You shouldn’t call him. What’s going on with work? Did they call you about the pilot? You shouldn't be smoking if you have a deadline.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Mom. Please. Don’t say deadline. Don’t say pilot. And do not, please, ever again, say the word Jacob, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Alright. (then) I just don’t think you should call him. Especially when you have a deadline on your pilot. Jacob, I mean. Lori bites her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: We should find you a hobby. (then) I thought you were gonna volunteer at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I keep meaning to do that. (then) Or maybe you could be my hobby. Lori looks up, eyes wide. A bagel POPS out of the toaster Mother and daughter both jump.  10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie steps up to the ticket counter.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Three for “Fight School”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie sits alone, eating popcorn in the back row of a Li Neeson movie. She enjoys the explosive action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie is being helped by FREDDY (20s, GENIUS T-shirt).

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: And you just put your fingers on the screen like this...

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, look at that, you magnified it. (squinting) So if I wanted to look up an address for a baby shower?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Well, you’d go on Safari and...

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh you just Google it?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah you just type it in. And if you need to find it again, it’s in your search history. There.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh my god Freddy, you really are a genius.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: (humble) It’s just a label.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Your mother must be so proud.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: I guess so.  11

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, I would be. My daughter’s a genius, but she’s too old for you. How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: I turn twenty-three in October.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Get outta here. Happy Birthday. What does that make you? A Libra? What does that mean? It’s the scales, right? Justice? You're probably very diplomatic. You should be a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You should. Marnie smiles. Freddy nods, not sure how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie, wearing black as usual, tries to mingle with vari 30-SOMETHING WOMEN at a fancy BABY SHOWER. -- Marnie stands on the outskirts of one group.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You should get the kind I have. Transitions. They go from regular glasses to sunglasses when you walk outside. You can find ‘em anywhere... Lenscrafters.... (pulling out her iPhone) You want me to make you an appointment? -- Marnie interrupts an ENGAGED WOI --

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re gonna want to clean that with Windex. -- To an INFERTILE WOMAN --

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you should do is have him tip you upside-down. That’s what Joe and I did when we conceived Lori.  12

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: And this one’s from Mrs. Minervini. Marnie sits among the much-younger group, feeling under- dressed, awkwardly squeezed next to a tree. They watch EM (30s, pregnant) unwrap a white box.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god... an iPad. The women “ooh” and “ah” at it, a bit confused.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow, Marnie, that’s crazy generous.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, I know it wasn’t on your list but I went to the Apple store the other day and I saw this little Filipino boy, practically a baby, playing on one of these, what do you call it’s...

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: ... iPads...

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: ... iPads... And then Freddy told me they have all these programs you can download, like Barney’s Circus and Nemo--

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Marnie. That’s sooo0o nice. Lori has the best mom ever. Emily moves on to other gifts. Marnie goes back to eating scone. The BRUNETTE (30s) sitting next to her, leans in.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNETTE
dialogues.text: Where is Lori?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I think she’s working today. She's got that deadline. I mean... countdown.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNETTE
dialogues.text: She said she’d baby-sit Tehya tonight. Dani and I haven’t gotten out in a year.  13 10.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, well I could-- A BLONDE WOMAN (30s) leans in.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE WOMAN
dialogues.text: I thought she was out of town. A CURLY-HAIRED WOMAN (30s) leans in, holding a TINY DOG.

dialogues.speaker: CURLY-HAIRED WOMAN
dialogues.text: She told me she was sick.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, she was sick....

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE WOMAN
dialogues.text: I'd be sick too. With everything Jacob puts her through.

dialogues.speaker: CURLY-HAIRED WOMAN
dialogues.text: She’s so pretty. Why can’t she just get over him?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNETTE WOMAN
dialogues.text: She's never gonna get over him if she keeps giving him what he wants. They all nod in agreement. Marnie looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What does he want?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: OMG shut it. Everyone turns back to Emily holding up a tiny onesie.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does this come in my size? I’m kidding. I know it doesn’t. The women ooh and ah at it, except Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What does he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie is standing by the buffet table, a pastry in one h her iPhone in the other. She texts Lori: Where r u?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie? 11. Marnie turns to see the mom-to-be with an OLDER MAN (60s)

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marnie, this is Greg’s dad. He came out to help us with the nursery.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: Mark, hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Marnie. She gestures with her hands full.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: He’s in town til Thursday. Emily walks away. It takes awhile for Marnie to finish he bite. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: So you're out visiting your son?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Emily said it was important that I come but... I think I’m just here to carry gifts. (laughs, then) His mother isn’t around.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my husband died a year ago.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, she lives in London, but, we're divorced.... Marnie takes a sip of her drink.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Emily said that you grew up in Brooklyn. Which, um, which part?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Near Sunset Park.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I lived on the corner of 48th and 7th right by the church.  12.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Get outta here. I was on 43rd and 4th right by the other church.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: We used to go to the public pool before it became a parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Get outta here. I went there every summer we weren't with my aunt at Greenwood Lake.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I bet we ran in similar circles.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Isn’t that funny? She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Well, maybe before I leave town, we can have lunch with the girls. Marnie stops, frozen, unable to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or there's this Holocaust museum I’ve been meaning to check out. Have you been to the Holocaust museum? Marnie finally exhales, flustered, and starts piling food her plate.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, no, I can’t, I’ve got so much to do, settling into my apartment, getting all my papers in order, plus I’m just about to start volunteering at the hospital... And maybe get into baby-sitting, so... She backs away from him.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (too loud) I’ve never been so busy. She puts down the full plate and scuttles away.

dialogues.speaker: PRE-LAP
dialogues.text: 14 15 16 17 18 13. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- DAY 14 Marnie drives while leaving Lori a voicemail, on speaker.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Anyway... I just wanted to tell you that I’m on my way to the hospital to volunteer. So give me a call soon or else I’1ll already be in there and it’ll be too hard to reach me, okay? Oh and I’ve been listening to the best Beyonce song! She turns up the volume, the same Beyonce song we’ve alre heard in progress. Marnie holds up the phone for a verse. Then lowers it:

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, I’m almost at the hospital so give me a call. Soon. Otherwise I’1ll already be in there. Okay. Love you. Marnie hangs up, then turns up the song. When it comes to end, she starts it over again. It continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the double doors, Marnie is frozen, hesitating to come inside. SOMEONE is wheeled outside, opening the door automatically. Marnie finally walks through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie sits among the sick and injured, filling out a volunteer form. She writes in her name and address. She puts down Lori as her emergency contact. She stops at marital status, unsure what to write. A HOMELESS WOMAN (40s) coughs loudly across from her. Mar looks up and gives a polite smile.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS WOMAN
dialogues.text: The demons are chasing me. With their dicks.  19 14.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, that must be scary.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS WOMAN
dialogues.text: It is. Can you buy me a Sprite?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Sure. Marnie puts down her volunteer form. And makes her way toward the VENDING MACHINES. She weaves in between patien and their ailments. Someone coughs. Someone cries. Marnie puts a dollar in the machine, pushes the button, n hearing the TELEVISION playing the NEWS above her.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE NEWSCASTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ... Within ten miles of where the skeletal remains were found. Police suspect this could be the work of a serial killer that's been targeting young women in the area since 2005...

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can I get my Sprite? Marnie jumps, startled, as the homeless woman takes the s and disappears. Marnie looks around at all the people in need and starts backing away from them all, panicked.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Sorry.... She quickly bursts out of the hospital doors. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- MORNING 19 Marnie unlocks the door with a key, holding a brown bag.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Lori? There’s no answer. Marnie greets the dogs, then rounds th corner, into the bedroom --

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t you get the mail anymore? Lori screams from inside the shower. Then pokes around th shower curtain.  15.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mom, I was shaving. You need to ring the fucking doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: But I have the key.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Well, what if I had company?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Who? Jacob?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: No. Who told you that? Marnie looks at the TV. A TEEN SOAP plays, MUTED. ON TV: HANDSOME ACTOR (30s) charms a PRETTY ACTRESS (20s).

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Your friends at the baby shower. Lori disappears behind the curtain again.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please don’t talk to my friends, okay? They’re not my friends. And you’re not supposed to plus one when there isn’t a one to plus.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, you never told me if you were going or not. Did you get my message about the serial killer? He’s been all over Southern California, targeting young women.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, we should be fine then.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Maybe we should have a system in place, like if you let me know every time you’re leaving the house and then text me when you get home.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Just until the guy is caught. And if you ever run into him, remember “Eyes, Throat, Crotch.”  16.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom, maybe you shouldn’t just drop by here all the time.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: But I barely see you. Marnie looks at Lori’s computer and does a quick scan of Lori’s SEARCH HISTORY. In reverse order: Jacob Mailer girlfriend 2015 > Jacob Mailer girlfriend > Jacob Mailer > weird color stool > green stool > least painful suicide > how much valium does it take to kill yourself > adoption agencies LA > adoption

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I just have a ton of work to do. And it requires a lot of research. Lori shuts off the faucet. Marnie quickly moves away from the computer and sits on the bed as Lori wraps herself in robe and steps out. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just saying, I’m in no shape to be entertaining right now. I don’t have any good stories.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Is there anything you want to talk about? Lori rushes into the living room. Marnie follows.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear what I just said? What I need to do is write, okay? This is my office. This is my desk. (gesturing to couch) These are my coworkers. (gesturing to dogs) If I was in a real office, you wouldn’t just come in and sit on my desk and pet my coworkers, would you? Marnie tries to answer correctly.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: No? Lori takes a breath.  17.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I've been talking to my therapist about it and I think we need to establish... certain... boundaries. Marnie tries to hide how much this hurts.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Sure. I get it. You need to work. I‘1l get out of your office. Marnie starts out. Lori feels guilty immediately.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: You don’t have to leave right now.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: No, it’s fine. Wouldn't want to cross peoples’ boundaries. 20 INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE -- LATER 20 Marnie sits across from DIANE (40s) perched in a papasan chair. Next to her, a desk and a RABBIT in a cage.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: And I just think she’s never gonna get over him if she keeps giving him what he wants. You know? And I think she’d feel better if she at least, you know, tried to get over him, but she just seems so angry all the time... I mean, you’ve been seeing her for awhile, did she always seem so angry? (no response) I just don’t want her to hurt herself or anything, I mean, has she talked to you about that? I’m not saying I want to know anything, I just hope that if she’s talking to you, she’s talking to you about the right stuff and that, you know, you tell her not to hurt herself or anything. And that she should quit smoking grass. I mean, I know she’s in some stage of grief or something....

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: And what about you?  21 18.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, I feel like she should find other ways to make herself feel better besides marijuana.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I mean, how do you feel since your husband died?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, of course I get sad. But I don’t think I’m as stressed as Lori is cause I don’t have to worry about a career or money. I mean, Joey left me set for life, so really I can do anything. Like when I go to an action movie, I always buy three tickets. One for me, one for Joe and one for my mother, and I don’t have to worry about it. I mean, I spend a lot of time by myself and sometimes I don’t really know what to do with the hours in the day so I call Lori, but it’s not like she really wants my advice or like I have anything important to say... (adrift, then) But basically I feel fine. I love my apartment. And of course you can't beat this weather. I mean, who doesn’t love The Grove? It’s like living on Main Street in Disneyland. Marnie smiles. Diane reaches for her notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Marnie unlocks the front door and locks it behind her. -- Marnie spruces the dead bonsai out on the balcony, try to bring it back to life. -- Marnie does a Sudoku puzzle on her phone. -- Marnie leaves another message after the beep.  19.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Anyway, let me know that you got in safe. Oh and remind me to tell you what your therapist said. -- Marnie makes a single cup of decaf, while watching TV; more about the serial killer called “Red Ripper”. Marnie tsks at the gruesome crime photos. -- Marnie takes forever to send Lori a text “Cl me”. The history of texts is very one-sided. -- Marnie falls asleep in bed next to her iPhone playing sounds of the ocean. The ceiling fan spins above Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie and Lori sit across from each other, both dressed black, surrounded by Valentine’s Day decorations.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: It’s so good to see you out of the house. And for such a nice occasion. Lori reaches for her drink. Marnie reaches for the bread.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mmmmm... Pretzel bread reminds me of my father. Well... pretzels. (then, to Heaven) And I got risotto for Daddy. Lori downs her drink. Marnie munches.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If Daddy saw me eating like this, you know what he’d say... (bad Italian accent) “Marnie, you're killing yourself.”

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: (trying to be funny) Well, you got the last laugh. Marnie smiles, but doesn’t laugh. Lori clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... listen, I have to go to New York for a few weeks. To shoot the pilot.  20.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: New York? Why?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Well, cause the show is set there, so it’s actually a good thing. But I wanted to tell you that I’m not gonna be reachable, like, at all, for a few weeks. Like someone else will be holding my phone for me. But I was thinking at the end of it, maybe you could come visit the set and we can finally think about getting a headstone for Dad. Or at least maybe figure out what to do with his ashes....

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Sure, we can talk about all that before you go. There’s no rush.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Well, I leave tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow? (sinking in) That’s really soon.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I know. But if you want to come over after dinner and help me pack and maybe even crash so you could take me to the airport in the morning, that’d be fun....

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, of course, but are you sure you don’t want me to come with you? I could be like your assistant.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: (quick) No. No, if anything I’d need you here. Watching the house and taking care of your grand-dogs. Marnie sighs.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s my job, Mom.  21.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: No, of course. You're right. That’s great news.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: It is. And it’s really good timing for me, you know? I can get out of town and be busy and finally take my mind off things. Marnie suddenly gasps.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Exactly-- Then Lori follows Marnie’s wide eyes to see JACOB (30s), handsome actor we recognize from TV. He comes toward them holding hands with a VERY TALL GIRL (20s). SOMEONE stops him/them for a picture. They finally reach the table.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: Hey, you two.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Hey. You two.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: Hey, Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Jacob, good to see you. I never had anything bad to say about you. Marnie looks down, trying not to say things.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: (to Lori) You know Elise.

dialogues.speaker: VERY TALL GIRL
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Yeah. They stand there awkwardly for a second.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: Well, we don’t want to interrupt your girl time.  23 22.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Oh no it’s fine. We’re just doing a drive-by before I head out later. I just didn’t want her to have to spend Valentine’s Day alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: And I didn’t want her to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I’m not alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: That's right. We're here together.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Until later. And then I’m with other people.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I thought I was sleeping over.

dialogues.speaker: VERY TALL GIRL
dialogues.text: Aw, that’s so cute. I wish my mom and I were that close.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, well, maybe when you get older. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- NIGHT 23 Lori charges in and slams the door behind her. The door t opens and Marnie walks inside, shutting it again.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What would make you happy? Lori flops onto the couch.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: If I could be stuffed into a cannon and shot into space.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Should we go get milkshakes? Lori screams into a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don’t we go to a waterpark this week?  23.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I’m going to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Don’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I can’t live here anymore, Mom. There’s no safe place. My TV is haunted. My job is make believe. And just when I wanted to hit the eject button, you move here.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: It means, I tried to book a session with my therapist to talk about my mother, and I couldn’t. Because my mother was there.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You said maybe I should talk to her after Daddy died. So?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Don’t you understand that eighty percent of the time my phone rings, it’s you? The phone rings, and I think it could be a guy or a friend or a job and it’s my mother. Almost every single time. Do you understand how terrible that makes me feel? Marnie blinks, stung.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, I could call you less. Like if I don’t hear back from you, I could just text you. Lori suddenly breaks down, sobbing. Marnie goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I’m never gonna get over him.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: How can I help? What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Nothing.  24 25 24. Lori pulls out her phone and starts texting.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Who are you texting? Don’t act out.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Mom, I need to have sex with someone else, and you can’t be here for it.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Okay, just not with Jacob. Lori's body explodes, shoving Marnie out of her room.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Please, Mom, I can’t do this anymore. I need to get a life of my own, okay? And so do you. Lori slams the door. Marnie sighs. A sad beat, then Lori talks from the other side of the door.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I still need a ride to the airport. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- MORNING 24 Marnie drives, Lori is quiet in the passenger seat. They make their way up to the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Do you have everything?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I have no idea. Lori kisses Marnie on the head, then drags out two suitca shutting the door behind her. Marnie watches her daughter until she gets safely inside. Then she slowly pulls away. We stay with Marnie as she drives ahead. The silence is deafening. Marnie quickly turns on Beyonce, humming along She reaches for her phone. About to call Lori. Then.... S puts the phone down. Both hands on the wheel. Determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie stands in the hospital hallway staring at a sign. “Volunteer Center” to the left. “Gift Shop” to the right.  26 27 28 29 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie strolls though the gift shop, scanning the differe stuffed animals. She decides on a STUFFED BUNNY. Its goof face makes her smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie strolls the halls with the stuffed bunny, trying t walk tall. There’s a LOUD BEEPING. Nurses rush through wi an emergency. Marnie starts to look uneasy. Up ahead, a MAN IN A GOWN (60s) dragging his IV. He’s com toward her. As he gets closer and closer to her, she turn away, pushing through a door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie ducks into the room and shuts the door behind her, noise of the hospital hallway is muffled. She looks up to see an OLD WOMAN (80s), lying in bed, mouth agape, no visitors. Something next to her is beeping. Marnie takes a few small steps up to the hospital bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Hello. She leans over to see some wires twisted under the woman’ twisted arm. Marnie reaches down and fixes the wires, mov her arm into a more comfortable position. The beeping sto

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is anyone here with you? The old woman slowly raises her arm. Her finger extends, pointing. Marnie lowers her arm, placing the stuffed bunn in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. I’11 get someone. Marnie slowly backs away and out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie quickly finds a NURSE (40s).  30 31 26.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, the woman in 142, I don’t know if she’s in pain. Could you just? The nurse walks off toward the woman’s room. Marnie watch feeling proud of herself, a smile curling on her face, as continues down the hall. PRE-LAP: A doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brunette from the baby shower, JILLIAN, opens the doo see Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNETTE/ JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Marnie? What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You said you needed a baby-sitter. Marnie holds up a brown bag.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I brought bagels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jillian cuts up a salt bagel for her daughter, TEHYA (4 y old).

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: I swear, I’m like the only one of my friends without full-time help. And in this town, it literally cost more than my salary to hire a decent nanny. So I quit. And now I’m home all day. All day, every day. Isn’t that right, Tehya? Tehya screams.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You could go into the nanny business. Jillian looks at Marnie and cracks up, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Oh my god. That’s like the funniest thing ever said, ever. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No wonder Lori’s so funny. Well, not anymore, but.... Marnie reaches out to Tehya, but she runs off to the othe side of the room to eat her bagel.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just nobody ever tells you how lonely it is. Like some days, I don’t think I talk to another grown person the entire day. Like by the time Dani gets home, I can’t even turn off the baby talk.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s normal.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: But just think, someday you and Tehya will be having like real conversations... You could talk about everything. Like me and Lori.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. You're right. I don’t know why I worry so much like I’m not doing it right. Like at any moment I’m gonna do the thing that gives her a body complex or a foot fetish.... I don’t know. I lost my mom when I was young so... I’m kinda flying blind. Jillian lets out a laugh. Marnie stops.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Lori said something about that, I’m sorry. (then) Well, anytime you need a baby- sitter, you can call on me. Jillian smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Lori's lucky to have you so close. If she ever has kids. My dad couldn’t even fly in for my fake wedding. I had to walk myself down the aisle.  28.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Aw. Why was your wedding fake?

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Because. It was at City Hall and we had just found out that the adoption had gone through and I told myself that I didn’t care about having a special day. I just wanted a quickie wedding and we'd have a real wedding sometime after we got Tehya home. But then I thought it'd be so selfish to spend any of the money I’d spend on her on having a special day, so.... Marnie looks at Tehya who is slamming a toy phone on the opposite side of the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What about Danny? Is he working?

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: She. Marnie tries not to react. If anything, it’s a thrill.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, Dani’s a chef at Bouchon, but she’s like fifth in line and she works crazy hours.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: She does.... The wheels are turning in Marnie’s head.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, what if I gave you the money?

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: What? Marnie turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, I can gift a certain amount of money to a person per year without having to pay taxes. I mean, I don’t know if it’s enough to make the wedding of your dreams but... thirteen thousand dollars?  29.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Marnie, that’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What’s crazy? I have it. You need it. Can't have it sitting there.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: You should save it. Spend it on yourself. I mean, wouldn’t Lori be upset?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Why? She’s not getting married.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: I just... I mean, why would you want to do that?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Cause. It sounds romantic. Like renewing your vows. Joe and I talked about that. I mean, who doesn’t love love? Jillian bursts into tears and leaps into Marnie’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Oh my God, this is so totally amazing. Of course you’re gonna be in on all the planning.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, only as much as you’d want... What do you think you’1l want?

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Oh I don’t know, nothing extravagant.... Dani was in the Navy, so... maybe it could be a nautical theme?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Yes. You could wear a sailor dress and she could wear her uniform. Like Officer and a Gentleman. (she gasps) You could do it on a submarine. CLOSE on Marnie’s face. More excited than the “bride-to-b  32 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddy helps Marnie look up things on an iPad.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: I don’t see any submarines for rent. But there are a bunch of boats at the yacht club in Marina Del Rey.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: And you can rent ‘em out for a party?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Looks like it. Marnie magnifies the screen, squinting at the boat image.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh Freddy, you really are a genius. Freddy smiles. Marnie squints at the boat price.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jeez, ten thousand dollars for just the venue? Marnie clicks a few buttons.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God, I really should get one of these for my daughter. Could you ring me up another iPad?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Sure. Freddy smiles at her generosity. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I decided to take your advice. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You’re gonna be a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Well, no, but... I’m gonna go back to school. Well, night school. Maybe engineering or programming, see how far I get. And work’ll pay for my classes, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Freddy. You took my advice. Marnie looks at him, smiling, proud, marveling.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Now I just have to figure out my work schedule. And the bus schedule.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You don’t have a car?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Well, my mom uses it for work. It’s okay, I like taking the bus. You get to meet a lot of freaky people.... Marnie doesn’t like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I could take you. When is it?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I’m in the neighborhood. Plus, you're always helping me out here. It'd be my way of paying you back. She hands him her credit card. He swipes it. 31. Then: She slides it back in her rubber-banded stack of cards. We see her husband's driver’s license on top of the pile.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We wouldn’t have to take the freeway, would we?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: We can avoid it. (then) But are you sure? It’s pretty late.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. She stares at the image of the boat.  33 34 35 36 32.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t sleep much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat from the picture stares back at Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie snaps pictures with her iPhone of every crevice of boat's insides, trying to get just the right angles. She texts Jillian way too many pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie browses the different flowers, thinking of the centerpiece possibilities. She takes pictures of various flowers with her iPhone. She pays for an assorted bunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie walks with the bouquet of flowers. A HOMELESS MAN (40s) is begging for change against a brick wall. Marnie stops in front of him, digging in her pocket for loose change. She pulls out a twenty and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: cut! A GUY WEARING A HEAD-SET (20s) comes up to Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: GUY IN HEAD-SET
dialogues.text: Are you supposed to be here?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GUY IN HEAD-SET
dialogues.text: Here. He backs her away from the homeless man. GUY IN HEAD-SET (CONT’D) On “background” you cross and talk to the woman in the blue hat. Marnie looks up at a WOMAN IN A BLUE HAT (50s). The woman smiles at her.  33. GUY IN HEAD-SET (CONT’D) (listening to his walkie) Losing the flowers. He takes the flowers away from Marnie and walks off. Marn looks around to see a CAMERA CREW is filming on this part the street. And she’s in the middle of it. GUY IN HEAD-SET (CONT’D) Okay, we’re going again. The “homeless man” pockets the twenty. Marnie is frozen, unsure of what’s happening, then:

dialogues.speaker: GUY IN HEAD-SET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Background!

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Ooh! She quickly crosses to the woman in the blue hat.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Action!

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: (to woman in blue hat) Hi, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN IN BLUE HAT
dialogues.text: Shhhhh... Marnie stops. The woman mouths words through a smile. Marnie tries to do the same, confused.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Anyway...

dialogues.speaker: GUY IN HEAD-SET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Background! Marnie crosses again. This time with more confidence.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The craziest thing happened, you would not believe.... I wandered onto a Hollywood movie set and ended up being a part of the action. Isn't that wild?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 37 38 39 34. Marnie eats lunch with the other extras. She laughs and talks to the woman in the blue hat.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They say that movie stars aren't nice people, but they really are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie says good-night to her fellow extras as she walks the edge of the set. Yellow signs marked TO SET point her back in its direction. As she reaches the perimeter of orange cones, she sees a IN UNIFORM (late 50s, too tan) leaning against a motorcyc He looks up at Marnie and gives a devastating smile.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Half day? He winks. She opens her mouth but nothing comes out. She quickly disappears around the corner and runs to her car.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don't think I'll go back but I'm glad I did it. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- NIGHT 38 Marnie drives Freddy to school.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then, three nights a week, I take Freddy to his class and we talk the whole way. (then, to Freddy) He scalps his victims while they’re still alive and then he eats their brains.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Sick.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I've been having a great time doing wedding planning with what's her name.  40 4l 42 35. Marnie uncovers Jillian's eyes, showing her the boat. Jillian gasps, excitedly. She pulls Marnie in and they wa down the ramp together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie and Jillian taste different cakes.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She seems really excited and loves all my ideas...

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Definitely the chocolate. The coconut.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: That’s true. A lot of people are allergic to chocolate. Jillian smiles at Marnie. Marnie smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I've been really getting into volunteering at the hospital. Marnie chats up a HANDSOME DOCTOR (30s) as he checks the woman’s chart.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You should come down here with me sometime and meet the staff. (to the doctor) Oh, you’re not married? That’s funny. My daughter’s not married. EXT. LORI’S HOUSE -- DAY 42 In the backyard, Marnie feeds Lori’s dogs, phone under he chin, pacing.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Anyway, just wanted to let you know I've been keeping busy with my own stuff and basically I feel great, so give me a call. I just want to hear that you’re safe and sound and hopefully you’re not thinking about Jacob too much...  36. BEEP. CALL WAITING.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Oh, is that you? Marnie clicks over.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Marnie, is that you? Marnie stops. For a moment, the voice is too familiar. Th Italian accent is strong.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s Tony. I’m here with Cos and Dominic and we all wanted to say hi. Here, talk to Dom.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ITALIAN MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Marnie. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Hi, Dom. How you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ITALIAN MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you coming back to Jersey for Joe's anniversary?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. Uh... I don’t know if I can come on the actual day, but I’ve been meaning to visit, so as soon as I’m settled, I’ll get ona flight and come see you guys. You feeling good? How’s Angie?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ITALIAN MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She’s good. You want to talk to her? (calling out) Angie!

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s okay, if she’s busy.... Each Italian accent is thicker than the last.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (taking phone) Marnie, where are you? When are you coming to visit?  37.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Hi, Ang. Soon, yeah. I just... can’t right now. I actually have a lot on my plate.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Have you thought about what kind a headstone you want to get for Joe? We were talking and Tony thought it should have a quote on it....

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sinatra.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, of course, Sinatra, but should it be “My Way”....

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Of course it should be “My Way”....

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ITALIAN MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t it be “My Way”.... Marnie’s head spins.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You know, I’m actually so busy planning this wedding right now and... dog-sitting... and I have to drive a friend of mine somewhere, so.... Oh shoot, Ang, there’s a problem with something, I have to go fix it, can I call you back? I’1l1 call you back. Marnie quickly hangs up. She stands there in silence, watching her daughter’s dogs finish their dinner. INT. JILLIAN’S HOUSE -- DAY 43 Marnie sits with Jillian, little Tehya, and the blonde wo from the baby shower, ELAINE. Marnie seems distracted, lo in thought, as they sift through online footage of variou wedding bands.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Unless you want like to spend a million bucks, bands suck. They just suck.  38.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: My sister had this Police cover band for her wedding. It hada lady singer. Elaine shows Jillian the band photo on her phone.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: She’s too pretty.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Maybe a DJ is more fun cause then you get to hear the real people sing the songs. Or what if you got a karaoke machine and then everybody just gets up throughout the celebration to sing dedicated songs to you?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: No... you have to get a band. Tehya wanders up to Marnie. Marnie immediately shifts her attention to playing with Tehya.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The venue is already so expensive. Maybe we should just pare this down. Stop all this planning. We don’t even have to meet up really.... We can do most of this over the phone--

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: No. Jillian turns to Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean... what if we start off by having a string quartet play when you come down the aisle? Then we have a DJ playing records while everybody eats. We get a kick-ass band for the big dance party, spare no expense. And, it might be fun to have a four-piece playing at the front of the boat the entire night. Like in “Titanic”. Jillian looks at her, overwhelmed.  44 45 46 39.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. This could be the only wedding I get to be a part of. I say we blow it out. Marnie puts her hand out. Jillian beams. She puts her han on Marnie’s hand. And they start laughing. Elaine puts he hand in the mix too. And they all squeal and scream.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we know who the flower girl is! They all tickle Tehya. Tehya laughs with glee. The sound a FOUR-PIECE takes us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie strides happily through the empty square toward th well-lit harbor of the Apple Store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks up to the Genius Bar. The door in back bursts open. Freddy emerges, still buttoning his shirt, flustere

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You okay? He hurries out of the store. She quickly follows. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- LATER 46 Marnie drives, Freddy is quiet next to her. Beyonce plays

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to say anything if you don’t want to. Is it a problem with work?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: He just always does this to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Your boss?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: No. My brother. He sends me an email, saying he wants to see me. I’m not even talking to him and he’s still telling me what to do.  47 48 40.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Why aren't you talking to him?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Cause he’s always getting me in trouble, man. Ever since we were kids. It’s like as soon as I get something good going, he tries to wreck it. (frustrated sound) He bailed me out one time and I’ve been paying for it ever since. She pulls over OUTSIDE OF THE SCHOOL.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You know, Freddy, sometimes I think it looks like a person doesn’t care as much, but really they’re just not as strong as you. (then) I bet it'd make your mother happy if you gave him another chance. Freddy exhales, really listening.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. He starts out.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. He shuts the door and walks off to class. Marnie looks pleased with her advice. She waits until he gets safely inside, then pulls away, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Marnie stocking up on stuffed animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie shows the old woman a stuffed bear. The old woman smiles. Marnie puts the giraffe under one of the woman's arm. Marnie shows her a stuffed elephant. And a bird. With each toy, the old woman smiles as much as she can. Marnie laughs as she places them all around the old woman head and throughout the room.  49 50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie is still smiling, as she’s handed a glass of 41. 49 50 champagne. Jillian is in the dressing room, while Marnie sits with, Emily, Elaine, the curly-haired woman AKA TRIS (30s), and TWO OTHER BRIDESMAIDS.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: I just don’t look good in strapless.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I don’t look good in anything.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: A wrap dress looks good on everyone.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: So how many bridesmaids are there now?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s me, Emily, Trish, Stacy, Casey... Katie M., Katie P., Molly... Gina, Amy, Fern... Windy, and... who am I forgetting? Lori. If she’s even in town.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: She'll be in town.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Cause the dresses are color coordinated and we need an odd number.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: She'll be in town. I’11 make sure.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Did you really book Blues Traveler?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: The guy with the harmonica? Oh yeah, he’s fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Okay, you guys....  42. Jillian emerges in a couture wedding gown. The women all crazy.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Oh that is it!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I could murder you.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You have seriously never looked skinnier.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Well, don’t fall in love with it, because I’m not gonna get this exact dress. I’m gonna copy it and buy cheaper fabric and have it made for half the cost. A STORE EMPLOYEE (20s) hears this and rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Jillian. Marnie stands and comes towards her.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You really look beautiful. They look in the mirror together.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you love it?

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Well, of course, but.... RIP. Marnie rips the price-tag off of the dress. The wome all gasp. Then Jillian jumps up and down. A flurry of gir screaming, then the women all envelop Marnie in a huge hu

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My mom was my birth mother, but would you be my Earth mother? The other women surround them in a group hug. The store employee joins in.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: My mom’s not dead but will you be mine too?  51 52 53 43.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Mine too!

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, you girls! They jump together in a circle, squealing and screaming.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Anyway.... INT. JILLIAN’S HOUSE -- DAY 51 Marnie and Jillian huddle around an iPad on a Crate & Barrel's bridal registry. Marnie helps Jillian click on different items.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I just wanted to make sure that you're gonna be back in time for what's her name's wedding. I don't think you're gonna want to miss it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie walks with Crate & Barrel bags full of everything Jillian's list.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's gonna be the party of the century. So hopefully you don't have to do reshoots or whatever. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- LATER 53 The car is filled with Crate & Barrel shopping bags. Marn shouts into her hands-free cell, on speaker.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Anyway, I hope you're having a good time. Marnie spots a YELLOW SIGN on a telephone pole: TO SET! S immediately follows the sign’s arrow.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm kind of dying to hear about everything. I miss you.... Suddenly, a RIGHT ARROW. TO SET! Marnie tries to change lanes, looking over her shoulder--  54 55

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But basically I feel fine, so give me a call or don’t if you can’t-- CRUNCH! Marnie looks up to see she has crashed her Toyota into the back of the car in front of her. She reaches for her cell.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) «.. Okay, love you. She hangs up. EXT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE -- DAY 54 Marnie gets dropped off in a TAXI CAB. INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE -- LATER 55 Marnie sits across from Lori’s therapist again, surrounde the Crate & Barrel shopping bags.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: And then I realized that Freddy doesn’t have anyone to help him with his studying. So I found out what classes he’s taking and what books they're using at the school and I found them on Amazon for half the price, so... you know, I could help him with his studying.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: And why do you think you're helping him?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Freddy? Well... he lives in a poor neighborhood and his mother works full time and all he really wants is an education.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: And what about Jillian?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, she didn’t get to have a proper lesbian wedding and I have the money so I figured, well, I could do that.  45.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What’s Jillian’s last name? Marnie stops, giving it real thought.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I think it starts with aG. Ora K. It’s definitely a consonant.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: A consonant? Marnie looks at the rabbit in the cage on the desk. The rabbit looks back.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marnie, do you think there’s some part of you that feels guilty that you have your husband’s money? Like you received this consolation prize that you don’t know what to do with? Or is there a part of you that thinks that maybe money is the way to save everybody? Or possibly even a way to stay in peoples’ lives and be needed? And maybe your relationship with Freddy and Jillian is all a way of replacing your own daughter and husband? Marnie looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie fluffs the many stuffed animals around the old wom

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: (scoffing) And I told her, I said, I don’t need to replace anybody. And why should I feel guilty for Joe's money? He came from nothing and worked his whole life for it. He would've wanted me to put it to good use. Like Cinderella. Bippity-boppity-boo. But she just kept saying all this stuff and asking all the questions. And I was like, you’re a therapist, aren’t you supposed to listen? Marnie then fluffs the pillow under the woman’s head. She looks up at Marnie, grateful.  57 58 59 60 61 46.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, this hospital is one of the best in the country. My husband died here, so you’re in really good hands. The woman slowly raises her arm and points her finger at Marnie. Marnie looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ET phone home? Marnie smiles and puts her finger on the woman’s finger. woman begins to make small half circles again, tracing th sky. Marnie’s finger moves with it. The old woman’s eyes are fixated on Marnie, but she’s stirring inside, trapped in her body. Marnie looks back, also stirring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie looks at her empty parking space. Then turns to th car parked in front of it, under the tarp. She walks to i and rather unceremoniously pulls off the tarp. She steps back. And the ceremony takes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie drives the sunny streets in Joe’s shiny, two-door, cherry-red Lexus convertible, palm trees reflected in the glass. INT. JOE’S CAR -- CONTINUOUS 60 She pushes a button. And the top goes down. She drives towards the sunset, wind in her hair, Beyonce turned up. INT. JOE’S CAR -- NIGHT 61 Grove parking lot. Marnie sits in the parked car, looking pictures of the bridesmaid dresses on her phone when a te comes through from a 917 number.  47. It reads: Hey Marnie, I'm in town again. Want 2 get that lunch sometime? xo Mark Marnie looks petrified, unsure how to respond when:

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Whoa, look at this. Is this yours? Freddy tosses his backpack in the car.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: No. Well, it was my husband's. So, I guess so. Just then, Freddy’s twin, FREDO (20s) appears at his side wearing a hat, also carrying a backpack.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO
dialogues.text: Got room for one more?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Marnie, this is my brother Fredo. Marnie’s eyes explode with pleasant surprise.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, wow, it’s so nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: I told him we'd give him a ride somewhere, is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: FREDO
dialogues.text: Actually I have to stop one other place first...

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Of course. Any brother of Freddy's is a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO
dialogues.text: Shotgun! 62 INT. JOE’S CAR -- LATER 62 Marnie drives, Freddy squeezed in back, Fredo up front.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: I read the book cover to cover, and you were right about that memorization technique.... (then, testing it out) The executive’s legs are juicy.  48.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Ooh, what’s that?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Executive, legislative, judicial.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO
dialogues.text: Does this top go down?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Sure. Marnie pushes a button and the top goes down.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is the kind of car I need. But I'd paint it black. Matte black.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Ooh, that’s an idea.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO
dialogues.text: (to Freddy) Hey, remember when Tre stole that car and it turned out to be a hearse? You pissed your pants! Fredo laughs hard. Freddy can’t help but laugh a little. Marnie smiles at them both.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is the place. Marnie pulls the car over. It’s not a great neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1ll be two minutes. Fredo takes his backpack and makes his way to a run-down house. Marnie and Freddy wait.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Thanks for taking him.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Of course. It’s just nice to see the two of you together. They watch as a THUG (20s) opens the door and lets Fredo  63

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you guys want, we can stop for ice cream on the way back. Freddy laughs, knowing that’s unlikely. INT. JOE’S CAR -- LATER 63 Marnie, Freddy and Fredo eat ice cream. She drives on.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO
dialogues.text: .+. Well, by then Freddy lost like thirty pounds and the doctors said if he didn’t get another kidney within three months, the toxins would spread through his entire body and he’d definitely die.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO
dialogues.text: I said, “Mom, Freddy’s the smart one in the family. I’m not worth saving, but he is.” (then, to Freddy) Show her the scar. Freddy rolls his eyes, then turns around and shows the sc on his lower back. Marnie marvels at Fredo’s generosity. She turns back to Fredo, showing his scar.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, we’re not so different. He points ahead.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here we go. EXT. CITY STREET/INT. JOE’S CAR -- CONTINUOUS 63A Marnie pulls the car over and Fredo zips up his bag and h out. Freddy climbs in the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: FREDO
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mrs. M.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: So nice to meet you, Fredo.  64 50. Freddy shuts the door. Marnie watches Fredo go. He waves. She waves back. He walks toward the seediest house ever.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Isn't it crazy? At one point, you were just these little kids who looked exactly the same. And now look at you. She pulls ahead. INT. JOE’S CAR -- LATER 64 Marnie pulls over in the parking lot of Freddy’s school.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: And what’s the difference between a veto and a pocket veto?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: A pocket veto is when the President doesn’t sign a bill for ten days but Congress can’t overrule it.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You're ready, Freddy. (laughing) Ha. Ready, Freddy. Just then, Freddy reaches down and picks something up off passenger seat floor, trying to hide it.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that? Freddy reluctantly shows her what he’s found. A plastic b filled with weed. She looks at it, disappointed. Then: ORANGE AND BLUE LIGHTS flash behind them.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh God. A FLASHLIGHT shines on the two of them inside.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cheese it! She looks at Freddy. He’s panicking.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: What do we do? What do we do? I can’t get in trouble. Not now.  65 51. A man is coming towards her. Marnie thinks fast. She take the weed by the handful and turns to Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Joey. Freddy watches as Marnie throws the entire chunk of weed her mouth and chews it. The man gets closer and closer. Marnie chews faster and faster. He’s at the window. She swallows. He knocks. She lowers the window.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPUS SECURITY
dialogues.text: Are you alright, ma’am? Marnie looks up at CAMPUS SECURITY (20s). Marnie shakes h head yes. The guy walks away. She looks back at Freddy. Her head starts shaking no. No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still on campus, Marnie drives as slow as humanly possibl Freddy beside her. The drugs move through her system.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: I am so so sorry, Marnie. I never should’ve let him in the car. I shouldn't even be talking to him again. Damn this stupid kidney!

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Freddy? I’m very something right now but when I’m not this we should talk about everything, okay?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: Okay. She rolls to a stop. Freddy climbs out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But Marnie?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Freddy?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDY
dialogues.text: I am really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I know, Freddy. I’m gonna get off the road now, Freddy.  66 67 68 69 52. He shuts the door. She looks at him for a stoned beat, th pulls away, ever-so-slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Marnie wanders The Grove, stoned out of her mind. The sights. The sounds. Everything is vivid, alive. -- The fountain is more mesmerizing than ever. -- The trolley is a locomotive. -- Outside the theater, she stares at a poster of Jacob i upcoming indie. Marnie’s mind explodes, like she’s seeing the universe through her daughter's eyes. -- The stores have closed. Marnie walks the full length o The Grove and keeps going, crossing into: EXT. FARMER’S MARKET -- LATER 67 She wanders through the cluster of closed restaurants. EXT. DUPAR’S -- LATER 68 She makes her way to the brightly-lit diner. INT. DUPAR’S -- LATER 69 She stares at the gigantic cakes and pies spinning in a g case. Her eyes are glazed over. She looks up at a WAITRES

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Howm... uch?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: They’re all twelve dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I can have them all for twelve dollars?

dialogues.speaker: COP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, I know you. Marnie turns to see the motorcycle cop from set. Out of uniform. He’s even better-looking up close. Marnie’s glaz eyes widen, starting to panic.  53.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Uh... No, you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You're an actress, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: And you are a police... officerman. She turns back to the pies, nervous, paranoid, feeling th weed. He steps up to her.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Well, technically, I’m retired. But they still need us on set. (making joke) In case a director starts throwing things. He laughs. She laughs, confused.

dialogues.speaker: COP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everybody calls me Zipper.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s nice. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: COP/ZIPPER
dialogues.text: And you are, Miss...

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Minervini.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Miss Minervini...

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Mrs.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Minervini...

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Or is it Miss? My husband died, but it’s still Mrs., right? Or do I go back to my maiden name? You know what? Call me Marnie, that way it won't be confusing. She steadies herself, trying to look casual.  70 54.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Marnie?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Do you want to join us?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Us? Marnie looks up to see an entire corner of the restaurant swarmed with COPS, some detectives, some off-duty. She tu ghost white. Zipper leads her toward them.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um... INT. DUPAR’S -- LATER 70 Marnie sits next to Zipper in the middle of the circle of COPS, some in uniform, some detectives, all chugging coff and talking a mile a minute. Marnie is staring at her han

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER LEE
dialogues.text: So we get to the area and sure enough there’s a naked guy and he’s just walking down the street, waving in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BERNIE
dialogues.text: He wasn’t waving. He was saluting. The cops crack up. The sound echoes through Marnie’s body She looks up from her hands.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER DAVIS
dialogues.text: Anyway, he was being real belligerent and refused to put any clothes on or get in the car. So Bernie suggested we taze him.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BERNIE
dialogues.text: (throwing up an arm) What can I say? I love tazing.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER DAVIS
dialogues.text: So Bernie gets his tazer out and... you know how Bernie’s aim has always been a little low...  71 55.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: No... Everyone dies of laughter. Marnie tries to join them, laughing too hard.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER DAVIS
dialogues.text: (laughing, shaking) He would not go down. He just stood there, vibrating, pointing north... (turns to Marnie) Pardon my language. Marnie stop and turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Were you talking? They all look at her, then everyone bursts into laughter. Zipper smiles. She laughs, unsure. EXT. DUPAR’S -- LATER 71 Zipper opens the door for her. She hurries outside.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Sorry about them. They’re good guys. They just like hearing themselves talk.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, if I had stories like them, I'd just like to hear myself think. He laughs. They stand at the edge of Dupar’s parking lot, under a street-lamp. She looks at him, knees weakening.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I better get home.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I gotta dog-sit my daughter’s kids and my hands are really loud, so...

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Do you need a ride or...? He gestures. Marnie looks at Zipper’s motorcycle.  56.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I can’t drive that thing.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: (slight laugh) Okay, well, how bout just this once I drive it and you can sit on back. He climbs on.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? I would kill my daughter if she died on a motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Oh, no, this isn’t a motorcycle. This is a Harley Davidson. There's a world of difference. It’s important that you understand that. A few other cops start out of Dupar’s toward their COP CA

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me just kick-start her here. Zipper “kick-starts” his Harley with his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You wanna go on a ride-along?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: A what-along?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: You're new in town. Let me give you the tour. She looks at him, unsure.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The safest place you can be in Los Angeles is on the back of this bike, I promise you. He extends a helmet.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I’11 go slow.  72 73 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not slowly, the motorcycle tails a COP CAR. Marnie is strapped to Zipper’s back, helmet on, terror in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: So tell me about your kids.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: She grips his waist and closes her eyes, starting to pray

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie and Zipper are parked behind the cop car. Zipper looks through binoculars at something.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: After I retired, I used to drive around listening to the CB just to see where the action was. And then I started following them around, so the guys said I should just come along. Sort of like unofficial back-up. In case anything goes wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: That’s cool. So you make your own hours. He swallows, letting her think it’s cool.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Were you on the Red Ripper case?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: No. No, but I knew of the guy following him. Hadn’t seen his family in eight years. That’s what chasing a rabbit will do to you. This hits her. She nods, letting go of irrational fears.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Took thirty years on the force to realize you can’t save everybody. He looks through the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you try.  74 58. Marnie smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a view of the pier, Marnie and Zipper sit on a bench the motorcycle nearby. She looks through the binoculars n like they’re in the last row of an action movie.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: So why do they call you Zipper?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: It’s my last name.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, well, that makes sense. What’s your first name?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Randy. Randall.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Are you from out here? Am I asking too many questions? He smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: I’m from Oxnard originally. I moved to Ventura when I got married and then I moved to Topanga when I got divorced.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t be sorry. She’s not. He laughs. She joins him.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She never smiled with her teeth. You know? I should’ve known. Marnie doesn’t know whether or not to smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Topanga? Is that by the beach?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: It’s by the beach. Not on the beach. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind living on the beach. But I wouldn’t know where to keep the chickens.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Chickens?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Some people have dogs. I am aman with chickens.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: You know what they say about counting chickens. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have a very symbiotic relationship. I give them a coop and some grass and sometimes a little Parmesan cheese and they keep me in eggs. He reaches into his pocket and pulls out a blue egg.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is from the Ameraucana. I only have one Easter Egger. He hands her the blue egg. She looks at it up close.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it didn’t break.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Yeah, she’s a toughie. (then) You want to meet her? She looks up at him, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You mean at your house?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: (looks at his watch) Well, she’s been out at the bar all night but she should be home by now.  75 60. She deliberates, fighting the voices in her head. EXT. ZIPPER’S TOPANGA HOME -- EARLY DAWN 75 Marnie and Zipper walk up to the coop. He holds open a chicken-wire gate and she nervously walks through it. She stands there as Zipper calls to the chickens and spreads some feed.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Okay, that’s Joan, that’s Gertude, that’s Henrietta... Don’t let her sass you. She’s got an attitude on account of being so damn beautiful. Ladies, this is Marnie.
