Marnie shyly waves at them. Zipper walks to the other sid of the coop and messes with a boom box, an extension cord extends into the house.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Couple a months back, I was cleaning the coop and playing my boom box and I looked at their faces and I swear, the chickens just looked happy. So I dida little experiment to see what kind of music they dig the most. Rock ‘n’ roll makes them lay eggs like crazy, but seems to stress them out. Classical works. Reggae does not. But I find for the perfect balance of productivity and happiness, all roads lead to Dolly. He pushes PLAY on the boom box and a Dolly Parton song pl Zipper and Marnie stand in the coop.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: How can you tell if it’s working?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Don’t they look like they’re smiling? She looks at the chickens. They all have different chicke faces. She can’t tell if they’re smiling, but she sure is It gets wider and wider, as she moves around the coop, tw stepping out of the chickens’ way. It’s almost dancing.  61. 76 INT. ZIPPER’S HOUSE -- MORNING 76 The sun is just coming up, bathing the room in a pink glo Zipper makes Marnie a cup of coffee in his small kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, Joe didn’t want to know how much time he had left. But Lori and I knew. So he asked her if she could throw us our wedding anniversary in August. But she knew he wouldn’t make it til then so she said, “Why don’t I throw you a party forty years from the day you met?” So Lori decorated her house like it was 1969 and all the music was from 1969 and all her friends came dressed in 60s clothes and Joe’s brothers flew out and she served fondue. And it was just the most spectacular day. Like the day we got married. Marnie smiles. Zipper sits across from her.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We came out here for his treatments and then took care of him for another two months and.... (smiling) Lori said we were in the delivery business. (hands to Heaven) Shipping and handling. She forces a smile. Zipper can see this is still an open wound. He moves on.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: And then you stayed in LA? That’s a pretty big sea change, literally. I mean, that’s really, very brave.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, who wouldn’t love it here? The sun is always shining. It’s like living on Main Street in Disneyland. He looks at her. For a second too long. And smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What about you? You got kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two beautiful girls. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The one who likes me lives far away. And the one that doesn’t is in Palm Springs. Her smile drops. He explains.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lizzy was still in high school when her mom and I fell apart, which was mostly my fault. 70/30. 60/40, maybe. I was working all the time. I brought it home with me. And as soon as she started to slip away, I started gripping and I guess I held on too tightly. And I lost her. Lizzy, I mean. The younger one. (then) She’s in a rehab-- (correcting himself) Program. She’s in a program. I was hoping one of those steps would lead her back here, but.... (then) I don’t know. I was a hot head then. I let my temper get the best of me. I was too strict. Had too many rules. Curfews. Made them scared to tell me things.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, sure. Look at everything you were seeing all day. Serial killers and stuff? I just watch the news. Never-mind being a part of it. It’s like an action movie.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: (slight scoff) Well, not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Still. It’s not your fault the world is a scary place. She takes a sip of coffee. He looks at her. how beautiful she looks. 62. She has no idea  77 63.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank God you’re retired. He clears his throat, almost laughing, but not.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Yeah, it has its moments. I’ve learned to calm down. I meditate, if you can believe that. The chickens keep me in line. Sometimes I hit the bag in the garage. Mostly I just exercise patience. With everything. My ex. My girls. If Lizzy doesn’t want me to call her anymore, I have to respect that.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: (bursting) No. I mean... you can’t not call.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: I left her messages until it was full.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: So? I’m sorry. I should mind my own business. But you should call her.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: I really wouldn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Just tell her you love her. No matter what she’s up to. (then, matter-of-fact) Everybody knows their mothers love them unconditionally. Fathers have to... say it out loud. I think. He smiles. Struck by this. Her. She can suddenly feel the weight in the air and barrels through it.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joe used to have a temper. But he was Italian, so.... Oh my God, what time is it? EXT. LORI’S HOUSE -- EARLY MORNING 77 Zipper pulls the motorcycle over and Marnie hops off. She hands him the helmet. He hands her a carton of eggs.  78 79 64.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Okay. He reaches into his wallet and hands her his card. Their hands touch for a flash. She quickly puts the card in her pants pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In case you need to get out of a speeding ticket or something. She turns and hurries away. He watches her go. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER 78 -- Marnie puts down the carton of eggs. -- Outside, she feeds the dogs. Watching them eat. -- She opens the carton of eggs and sees eleven brown egg and one blue one. She smiles. -- Music begins over: INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- LATER 79 -- Marnie takes a piece of bread and cuts a hole in it. -- She places the bread in a hot pan. The butter sizzles. -- She cracks the blue egg open and drops the yolk in the center of the bread. -- The egg fries in the heat. The steam rises up to meet her. She slides the spatula underneath it and flips it at exactly the right time. -- Marnie sits at the table and cuts into the egg-fried bread. She salts the single bite and puts it in her mouth It’s so good, her eyes roll back. -- Bite after bite, it seems to only get better. She hasn tasted an egg like this in so long. Maybe ever. -- Marnie finishes the last bite, wipes her mouth and pou a fist on the table, as she swallows. And exhales. Slowly her expression changes from ecstasy to something like gui -- At the sink, she scrubs the plate clean, shaking her h  80 81 82 83 84 65.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Anyway... INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- LATER 80 Marnie packs a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm taking United flight 352 landing at JFK at 4:30. Just thought I should head back east for a little bit. See Daddy's brothers and maybe get to visit you on set.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the dogs. I dropped them off at Jacob's house so they'd be somewhere familiar. Marnie hands the dogs off to the tall girl from Valentine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie looks out the tiny window at the incomparable New City skyline. Her eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: To be honest, I can't wait to be back in the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets are alive. Marnie walks along the bustling sidewalks, taking hundreds of pictures with her iPhone.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Seeing the old stomping grounds. Walking through Midtown and the garment district and seeing Daddy's old building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie takes a picture of herself under the address, but off half her face. She looks up at the skyscraper, people flowing in and out, unable to bring herself inside.  85 66.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But mostly I can't wait to see you. So let me know when's a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The set of Lori’s TV pilot. Lori looks frazzled, surround by a crew of people asking questions, as Marnie approache smiling proud, clapping excitedly. Lori looks up at her a smiles wide, coming in for a long hug. Then, pulling away

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Okay, this is your chair. She sits her mother in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are your cans. She hands her mother a pair of headphones.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t talk to anyone. And the safe word is “cantaloupe”. ON A BELL. Marnie puts on her headphones, already on the edge of her seat. Lori sits behind the DIRECTOR (40s). Marnie sits behind Lori. Marnie peeks around them all to look at the tiny monitors, A and B. A clapboard comes into view. Rolling. Set. Action. ON THE A-MONITOR: A TV DAUGHTER (20s, too pretty) says go night to a DATE (20s) at the door.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: Okay, call me. Good-night. Bye. She shuts the door, swooning, then walks into the kitchen find -- ON THE B-MONITOR: The TV MOM (40s, too young) sits at the table, eating ice cream from a carton and reading a book. TV DAUGHTER (CONT’D) Jesus, Mom, you scared the crap out of me. Don’t you have ice cream in the guest house?  67.

dialogues.speaker: TV MOM
dialogues.text: Well, yeah but I already picked all the cookie dough out of it.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: What are you reading? (then, freaking) Is that my journal?

dialogues.speaker: TV MOM
dialogues.text: Oh, is that what this is? I thought the characters seemed a little slutty.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: Give me that!

dialogues.speaker: TV MOM
dialogues.text: Aren’t you too old to keep a journal?

dialogues.speaker: TV DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: Aren’t you too old to read your daughter’s journal? That’s a violation of space and time.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s all the yelling about? A TV DAD (50s, bad Italian accent) enters in nothing but towel. He fills the frame, taking over the B-CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: TV MOM
dialogues.text: I violated space and time.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAD
dialogues.text: You peed in the upstairs shower too? The director chuckles. Lori looks pained. But Marnie is mesmerized. The father and daughter talk, their images facing each other on opposite monitors.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with the shower in the guest house?

dialogues.speaker: TV DAD
dialogues.text: It started to get this weird smell. SLOW PUSH on Marnie. For a moment, Joe is alive. She watches without blinking, riveted.  68.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAUGHTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad, when I said you guys should move here after you retire, I didn’t mean here here. I need to get a life. I need to meet a guy and get married and give you grandchildren so you’1ll leave me alone. Wet towel, Dad. Wet towel.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAD
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. The dad removes the towel and hands it to the daughter.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Could you hang this up for me? (then) Lorraine?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaand.... cut. Everyone stands up and starts moving, back to work. Lori goes to talk to one of the CAMERA GUYS. But Marnie is frozen in place, dazed, nostalgic. Until: The actor playing the father comes to sit at video villag Marnie is a chair away from him as he checks his phone. S tries not to breathe. Then can’t help herself, and leans

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You look so much like him. He turns to her. No Italian accent.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: The character you're playing. You look so much like the person it’s based on.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAD
dialogues.text: Oh. I didn’t realize it was....

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Cantaloupe, Mom. (clearing throat) Cantaloupe. Lori gestures to her mother, while over-coughing.  86 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a round booth, Lori sits in between Marnie and the cam guy from Lori’s set, BEN (30s). He’s in the middle of a long, animated story.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Indy races through the jungle, all the way back to Jock and the seaplane. Indy screams, “Come on, Jock! Get going!” but the natives are chasing him to the edge of the water. So Indy grabs onto a vine and goes swinging through the air... Ben sings some theme music. Marnie laughs, enchanted. Lor takes a big sip of her drink.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Indy hits the water. Splewsh. Poison arrows are firing all around him. Pew pew pew pew pew.... Then Indy climbs into the seat of the plane just as it lifts out of the water and takes to the sky. And that’s when Indy looks down and sees.... are you ready?... a giant snake in his lap. Marnie gasps.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Indy screams, “Jock, why is there a snake on this plane?”. And Jock says, “Oh that’s just Reggie!” And Indy says, “But Jock, I hate snakes!” And the plane flies off into the sunset. And that’s the first twenty minutes of “Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Ark”. Marnie claps, entertained. Lori forces a laugh. Ben laugh the hardest, wiping his brow, and exhales.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I've never seen it.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Well, we’ll have to watch it before you leave town.  70. He gives Lori a too-hard squeeze. The WAITER brings more drinks. Lori can’t get to hers fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: So you guys met on set?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: (pointed) That's right, just two weeks ago. Like I was telling you right before you invited him to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, I think it’s romantic. Meeting on a movie set.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: People meet on sets all the time and it’s usually scandalous and home-wrecking.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I knew my husband for two weeks before he proposed.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Two weeks?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I think when you know, you know, you know?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I totally agree. He pulls Lori towards him.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I’m gonna run to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hurry back. Lori slides under the booth and away. Ben looks around, t looks back at Marnie, with a secret.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey... He gestures for Marnie to lean in. As she does, he leans forward and presents an ENGAGEMENT RING in a light-up box

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh my God...  71.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I got it the day after we met. (then) I don’t do things half-assed. When I know I want something, I go for it. That’s how I got this far in my career. Russell Boyd, Rodney Charters, Don McAlpine... when the top cinematographers need a B- camera operator, do you know who they call?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You? He shuts the ring box and leans back.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: When you know, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Wow, it’s all so fast. But if it’ll make Lori happy... He leans in, too intense.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: So I was thinking that we get everyone she knows, all her friends and family and people she works with and the entire crew and we put together one of those Youtube videos, and maybe it starts with you putting Lori on the back of my truck and then the radio starts playing our song... Marnie beams. Her eyes couldn’t get any wider.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And everyone she knows comes out one at a time and does this choreographed dance number until it ends with me appearing with the ring and getting down on one knee, all in one tracking shot....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lori rummages through the mini bar while Marnie sits up i bed, smiling too wide, practically vibrating.  72.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I just feel like the whole thing is getting bastardized by everybody's notes and the guy playing the dad is just not up for the challenge. Why are you so hyper?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Nothing. I’m just excited for you. (then) And Ben seems nice.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, don’t get too used to him, Mom, it’s not gonna last.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: (sing-songy) I wouldn’t be so sure.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: No, I’m telling you. I’m just rebounding. I need to date below- the-line for a change.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You know, sometimes, people think they’re having a rebound but then it evolves into something more. (then) Actually, there’s something I should tell you. Marnie sits Lori down. She takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was engaged to someone else before Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. You told me before.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I did?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Yeah, his name was Matteo and you weren't that attracted to him and then you went to Atlantic City with your girlfriends and that’s where you met Daddy. You have like three stories, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. So, if you’re rebounding then why don’t you and Jacob give it another go? Lori gets up, downs a quick drink.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: That’s not up to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe if you just told him how you feel....

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: See, that is the great lie of your life, Mom. That if you dream it, you can do it. And the world doesn’t work that way.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You dreamt you could move to Hollywood and you did it. You dreamt you could be a writer and you did it. You dream up different stories all the time. Lori half-smiles. It’s almost working.

dialogues.speaker: MARFNIE
dialogues.text: Which reminds me, I met the cutest girl in the bathroom at JFK. She's in a wheelchair and she writes a blog about empowering young women and I told her you were a writer and she hadn’t heard of you but she was really impressed when I told her you’d have coffee with her sometime and give her some industry tips. Your cell phone’s 323? Lori stops smiling.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I don’t have industry tips.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s just a coffee. She’s in a wheelchair. Lori climbs into bed next to Marnie, drink in hand. 73. Marnie has her cell phone out, camera on, unsure where to aim it  88 74.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do you take a selfie?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: What do you mean? You just take it. You just take a picture of yourself. (immediately curious) Who are you sending a selfie to??

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Nobody. Shhhhh. Marnie quickly puts her phone down, then grabs the remote

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: (playfully) Do you have a new friend??

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I said I didn’t want to talk about it! Lori stifles her happy curiosity as much as she can. She toasts the air, takes a sip of her drink and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lori is passed out in bed. Marnie pours a tiny bottle of vodka into a cup and into her mouth. Marnie swallows it i one gulp, then reaches for her phone. She squints to see the phone number written on his card. Dials before she changes her mind. Straight to voicemail:

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is obviously me. BEEP. Marnie loud-whispers in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Hello. Zipper, um, it’s Marnie. Minervini. I’m in New York with my daughter who is making her TV show and I saw the set today and it made me think of you. Well, your job. And also what you do for a living. She gestures and hits the table, knocking over bottles.  89 90

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, I ordered the scrambled eggs at the hotel this morning and they were nothing like what I ate of yours. I mean, the eggs you gave me. I had one. Briefly. So I just wanted to check in... on the chickens and, oh... (whispering more) Lori has a new boyfriend, or should I say fiancee... so give me a call, okay, love you. I mean, bye. She gasps, hanging up as quickly as possible, then tosses phone out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Marnie is pulled in by Joe’s surviving brothers COS, TONY and DOMINIC (60s).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie eats dinner with Joe’s brothers and their wives. ANGIE (60s) is among them.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: You lost weight.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: Here. Mangia. Angie dumps food on Marnie’s plate.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Ooh, Angie, ariancini. They don’t have anything like this in Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: Of course not. They don’t have anything like this anywhere. Only my mother made these and now I make them and I take the recipe to the grave. Marnie turns to two other wives. 89 90  76.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Tina, Pina, how are you feeling? TINA and PINA (60s) both make hand gestures. cos Hey, how’s the TV show?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: So funny, you wouldn’t believe it. I don’t know where she gets her characters from. Marnie takes a bite and makes food noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue to eat and talk loudly.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: The first time I cooked for Joe, I wanted to make him pasta. And my mother told me that you know if pasta is done is by throwing it against the wall and if it sticks, you take it out of the water. So I had the water boiling and I broke the pasta in half... The Italians let out a collective “ugh”.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughing) And then I cooked it and threw it against the wall and nothing. So I cooked it some more and then a little bit more until it finally stuck on the wall and stuck to the pot and stuck to itself and stuck to everything it touched. Marnie laughs. The group laughs along, knowing the story.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After he took the first bite, I saw him take a little pasta off of his plate and put it in his napkin and I said, “What are you doing?” And he said, “I just have to show this to my mother.”  77. They howl with laughter, hitting the table. Then one by o they laugh into sighs. Marnie is the last, wiping away laughing-tears.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it’s his anniversary already.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I know. A whole year. They look at her.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: You mean, two years. Marnie recovers.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Right. A year since last year.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: Time flies. cos Time flies.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So, we were thinking that half of his ashes could stay with you and Lori in California and the other half could be buried in Elizabeth with our mother and father. That way we all have a place to go. Marnie swirls the food on her plate.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know, I really just want to talk to Lori about it first? She's been really sensitive about it lately and I just don’t want to cause her too much stress while she’s doing the tv show.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Well, we talked to her and she said it was up to you. Marnie stops, out of excuses.  92 78. cos Maybe since we’re all on the east coast for a change, we could at least pick out a headstone.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Lori said you wanted to use a quote maybe?

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: Something from “My Way”. Marnie looks at them all, starting to sweat. cos It doesn’t have to be “My Way”.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: How could it not be “My Way”?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: As long as it’s Sinatra.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: Well, of course it’s Sinatra. cos Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: But it’s totally up to you, Marnie, if you want to bury his ashes here with our parents or if you wanted to sprinkle a little here and a little out there.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: “A little here and there?”

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: How could it not be “My Way”? The brothers talk over each other. Marnie can’t catch her breath. Panting. Panicking. The walls caving in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Departure gate. Marnie gives her license to AIRPORT SECUR (30s). The man looks up at Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT SECURITY
dialogues.text: Joseph Minervini?  93 94 79.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What? (realizing) Oh. I handed you my husband's license by mistake. She puts his license back on top of her rubber-banded sta of cards. And pulls out her license, handing it over.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT SECURITY
dialogues.text: Marnie Minervini. That makes more sense. And where are you headed today, Mrs. Minervini?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Los Angeles. I live there now. Marnie stands up straighter, saying it out loud. The security guy hands back her license.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT SECURITY
dialogues.text: And how was your time in New York? Marnie takes her license.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Great. My daughter shot a pilot. The guy looks at her, not letting go of the license, then gestures for an ARMED SECURITY GUARD. Marnie’s eyes widen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie sits in her seat, staring at Joe’s license at the of her stack of credit cards. She starts to cry, leaning toward the window so people can’t see. She doesn’t make a sound. The tears fall until they don’t. Then, she pulls o Joe's license, and slides it into the middle of the stack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane lands on the tarmac. Marnie wakes up with it.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Welcome to Los Angeles where the local time is 9:37am. Please remain in your seats while we taxi to the gate. If your cell phone is in reach, you may use it now. Marnie straightens herself, then opens the window shade, sun blares through.  95 96 80. She lowers it halfway, then pulls out her cell phone and takes it off AIRPLANE MODE. She looks at it, then sets it her lap. IT BUZZES. She picks it back up, surprised to se a NEW VOICEMAIL. An UNKNOWN CALLER. She pushes PLAY.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Marnie, it's your new friend Zipper. (she sits up) Or Randy. Depending on who you ask. I just saw that you called. Sorry I'm just getting back to you now. There's such bad reception in the canyon, I could barely hear your message. Marnie exhales, a bit relieved.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: But I wanted to try you back and see how the east coast is treating you. And also let you know that the chickens have expanded their musical library to include Peggy Lee, as well as Dolly Parton covers, so you've got that to look forward to. If you ever make it back this way. But... give me a call if you get a chance. Okay. (then, being funny) Love you, bye. Click. Marnie’s eyes widen. She covers her mouth, shocked unable to breathe. Then, she cracks up, laughing. And goe to listen to the message again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Marnie walks up the glass steps. -- Marnie combs the accessories department. -- Marnie buys a SPEAKER SYSTEM from an APPLE EMPLOYEE (2 Marnie looks around for Freddy but doesn’t see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie pulls the red Lexus up in front of Zipper’s house climbs out, holding the Apple bag. She walks up the front step. There’s music playing inside. As she gets closer, s realizes it’s Zipper, singing and playing guitar.  81. She stops short, listening through the screen door. It ta a moment to recognize the song, Dolly Parton’s “To Daddy”

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: (singing) Being took for granted was a thing that she accepted/ And she didn’t need those things to make her happy / She didn’t even seem to notice / That he didn’t kiss and hold her/ If she did, she never did say so to daddy.... Marnie mouths along with the lyrics, getting lost in the song. She leans against the screen door and it CREAKS. Th guitar stops. She quickly hangs the bag on the door knob starts away. The screen door swings open.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This counts as trespassing. She turns back to him. He “hides” an acoustic guitar.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You didn’t hear any sort of music- type sounds coming from inside....

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, was that you? He steps out.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Just a little Dolly cover band I’m putting together. Zipper and the Fuzz. We have a mostly avian fan- base. You want to come in, let me test this out on a human lady? He holds the screen door open, then notices the bag.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s nothing. I just thought you could use it to play music for the chickens. He opens the bag, seeing a Beats home speaker system insi

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can plug it in your iPhone. Oh, God, do you have an iPhone?  82.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: I have been meaning to get one of those. Thank you. You wannna come in? Show me how to plug it in? She looks at him, her courage waning.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I’m supposed to be at this wedding.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Oh. That’s fun. He walks down the steps towards her. She swallows.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I missed ya. (then) Isn’t that funny? She doesn’t know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ended up calling her. My daughter. Marnie smiles, genuinely excited.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Zipper, that’s great.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Yeah. She yelled at me. A lot. I’m thinking I should ride out there and let her scream in my face a little. You wanna come with? He reaches out and takes hold of her hand. She’s stunned, silenced.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just a day trip. Nothing overnight or... I just thought you should check out the desert and... I could use the moral support--

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I can't. She rips her hand away. He puts his hands in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softening) I... um... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t do that right now.... (then) Anyway, I just wanted to give you the speaker and tell you that I probably won’t be around for a little while. I need to go back east and... I just won’t be around. He looks at her, hurt, disappointed, but understanding.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Okay. He doesn’t move. Marnie turns away. And starts toward her car. She doesn’t turn back. He lets her go. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- LATER 97 Marnie stands in her black clothes, looking at her daught RED BRIDESMAID DRESS hung in front of the closet. She shakes her head, takes a breath and begins to undress Throwing off her black top. Kicking off her black pants. She wraps herself up in the red dress. She looks stunning transformed. She turns to the side and exhales. Okay, it’ a bit tight. But the color of the dress puts the roses in her cheeks. She tries her hair up. Then down. Then up. She paints her never-painted nails. She slides on lipstick. She puts contacts, leaving her glasses behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She parks her husband’s car near the harbor and hurries toward the twinkling strings of lights that lead to the b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie steps onto the boat just as it starts to leave. The water churns. Marnie races up the stairs to THE BOW OF THE BOAT, where bridesmaids stand in a row, wearing their color-coordinat dresses. They look flustered until they turn and see Marn in the red dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 84. Marnie joins the back of the line, creating a perfect rai of color. Jillian gives her a squeeze, sighing, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Tehya, come here. Emily tries to wrangle Tehya, dressed as the flower girl, she runs to Marnie’s side.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I got her. ON THE TOP DECK -- A string quartet begins to play. And o by one, the bridesmaids make their way down the aisle. Marnie is at the end of the line, twice their age but jus gorgeous, holding Tehya’s hand. She waves hello to the people she knows. She spots Emily' husband GREG (30s), and his father, Mark, near the front. Mark smiles at Marnie. Marnie smiles back. And the music begins. Everyone stands. Jillian is walked down the aisle by her SMILING FATHER (7 The bride looks beautiful in the overdone dress, beaming, near tears, as she reaches her wife, DANI (30s, dress whi with her BRIDESMEN & WOMEN and the boat’s CAPTAIN (40s). Everyone is a-glow. Especially Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat moves across the calm harbor waters, as the part starts on the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie holds her number, shyly looking for her table. It’ beautifully lit, filled with flowers, and simply beautifu

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Marnie, everything looks incredible.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, isn’t it pretty?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Over here, Marnie.  101 85. Emily waves Marnie over to the bridesmaids table. She is surprised to take a seat next to the other girls.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marnie, you really did it.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Can you believe how gorgeous this is and it’s all thanks to you. Marnie looks around, seeing her touches everywhere. She h to admit -- it’s quite remarkable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie and the rest of the guests watch Jillian’s wife Da finish her speech.

dialogues.speaker: DANI
dialogues.text: -.. And that’s when Jillian turned to me and said, “Now about that pilot’s license.” The room laughs, including Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: DANI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jilly Bean, I know people could've thought we were fools rushing in, but I want to spend the rest of my life getting to know you. Marnie nearly sheds a tear. Everyone cheers as the couple shares a sweet kiss. Jillian takes the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Thank you guys so much. There are so many people in this room that made this day possible, I can’t believe it. First, my incredible wife who married me a year ago against her better judgment.... (laughing) And then agreed to do it again in front of everyone we love, cause she knew it was important to me. Everyone awwwws. They kiss.  102 86.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to thank all of my bridesmaids. Nobody could ask for thirteen better friends. I love you all so much. Marnie and the other twelve bridesmaids smile.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I want to thank my family for flying in from all over the country. Daddy, I love you. (blows a kiss) And Marnie... Marnie stops, looking up, surprised to hear her name.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (starting to cry) There are no words to describe my gratitude. I have never met anyone More generous and truly selfless. When my mother died, I never imagined that I could feel loved so... unconditionally... by someone who wasn’t in my family. You are proof that when one angel leaves this Earth, another angel takes its place. I love you. To Marnie! Everyone holds up their glasses and cheers.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: To Marnie! Marnie looks around at everyone toasting her. She is overwhelmed, tears welling up in her eyes as she takes it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blues Traveler plays on-stage while everyone dances. Marn is among them, shoes off, shaking what the good Lord gave her. She dances with the other bridesmaids. Jillian swings Tehya onto the dance-floor and into Marnie arms. Marnie beams as she dances with the little girl, holding hands with Jillian. They make a circle. Emily joins the circle. And so does Mark. Marnie and Mark dance with Tehya between them. They boogie and jump and scream along to the music. Then:  87.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN POPPER
dialogues.text: This is a newer one. The band plays a slower song. Marnie and Mark stand there catching their breath.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I can’t remember the last time I danced this much.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I know. When I was a kid, we always went out dancing. I’m always telling Lori, “Why don’t you go out dancing?”

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You know, you did a really amazing thing, Marnie. All of this. They look really happy. Marnie turns to see Jillian and Dani slow-dancing, happy. She smiles. Then, just beyond them, Jacob crosses through group of people on his way out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So about that lunch....

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Would you excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Oh-kay. Marnie runs away from Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob walks to the bow of the boat, lighting up a cigaret

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Jacob! He turns to see Marnie racing up to him, without shoes, o of breath.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: Hey, Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Listen... She huffs and puffs.  104 88.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: She loves you. (then) Lori loves you, you know. And I know because I see how unhappy she’s been since you guys split up. And I know people are supposed to make their own happiness, but she’s never been that way. Or maybe she used to be, but not anymore. And I don’t know if it’s too late for you guys and maybe this is totally awkward and I’m overstepping my bounds, I know I’m overstepping my bounds, but it doesn’t matter. Cause if there’s even the slightest chance that you could end up with her, and make her happy, then that’s all that matters to me. Her happiness is all that matters. So what do you say? She stops. He looks at her. Takes his time.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB
dialogues.text: Marnie, I.... I’m sorry. Marnie looks at him, devastated, silenced. Just then, the very tall girl appears at Jacob’s side.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Hello, I was just leaving. Marnie turns on her heels and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat is docked in the background. Marnie fast-walks toward her car, Mark trailing behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t want to stay for another drink?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: No I really have to get back to.... Marnie arrives in her empty parking space. Her car is not there. She looks around, confused.  89.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Huh. 105 INT. MARK’S CAR/EXT. LORI’S HOUSE -- LATER 105 Mark pulls over in front of Lori’s house, as Marnie finis up a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Okay, thank you... (hangs up, to Mark) Well, looks like it was stolen.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Oh my God. The crime in this city. She doesn’t realize Mark is facing her.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sorry this is how your night's ending.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: That’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Can’t remember the last time I had so much fun.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Well.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Couple of Brooklynites, we are.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: And that dress is a knockout. (then) The color. Blood red. Mark touches her face. Marnie stops, frozen.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And hair to match. Suddenly his touch feels strange. He puts his hand on the back of her neck. Marnie’s eyes widen, as Mark’s eyes clo She can feel his grip. He leans in. And she explodes.  106 90.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Eyes, Throat, Crotch! Marnie pokes Mark’s eyes, chops his throat, punches his balls.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Ow! Marnie! What are you doing? She bursts from his car door and runs in a zig-zag patter away from him. He is not chasing her. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- LATER 106 Marnie locks every lock behind her. Then frantically fumb for her cell phone, quickly CALLING LORI.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Pick up, pick up, pick up....

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom? Marnie jumps. And looks up to see Lori.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You're home. Lori is holding her laptop.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: You gave my rebound guy every single one of my contacts so he could propose in a video?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Uh--

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: That’s gonna be fun to explain to everyone I know, including Jacob, who I have to see right now because that’s where my dogs are, so that’s not uncomfortable. Lori’s phone buzzes. She answers, while walking out of th room. We stay with Marnie. LORI (0.S., INTO PHONE) (CONT’D) Emily? (then) Wait, what? Slow down. She did what? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: 108A
dialogues.text: 109 gl. LORI (0.S., INTO PHONE) (CONT’D) (then) Are you kidding? Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie walks up to the store. She stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddy helps a NERDY GIRL (20s) with her phone. Marnie watches Freddy for a moment, seeing him in his element, a home in his work. Freddy makes the girl laugh. Marnie smiles to herself, proud of Freddy, knowing that h going to be okay, knowing she can’t go inside. Still smiling, Marnie turns away and out of the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as she does, A BELL RINGS. Marnie snaps out of he smile and sees that she’s standing on the trolley tracks. The TROLLEY is heading straight for her and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie rubs lotion on the old woman’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: See, every year the writers pitch the studios their ideas and then the studios choose a small percentage of those ideas to pay the writers to write the pilots, and then out of those scripts, they only pick, like, five percent of the pilots to actually shoot. I mean, film. And then only a handful of those pilots makes it to the air. And then only a handful of those gets to stay on the air. Seinfeld.... Marnie lets go of the woman’s arm but it stays in place, pointing at Marnie.  92.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who? Me? The old woman’s finger moves. Marnie turns.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want me to put on the TV? Marnie reaches for the remote.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought you didn’t like the news. The old woman traces the air with her finger. Making smal half circles over and over. Marnie looks at it. Like a puzzle. Trying to decipher it. Just then, Marnie’s cell phone rings. She looks down to s LORI CALLING. Marnie can’t answer fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom. I need you. INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- LATER/DAY 111 Lori opens the door to find Marnie holding a paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Did you bring ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. Lori grabs the paper bag. Marnie follows her inside.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Those are the bagels. Marnie holds up a plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are the pregnancy tests. Lori grabs the plastic bag. Starts towards the bathroom, Marnie following.  93.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Why did you get the jumbo pack?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know how many times you have to take it. Lori rips open a box and unveils a white stick.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Please don’t watch me pee on a stick? Marnie turns her whole body the other away.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not really that late, for me. It’s probably just stress. I can’t stop sleeping, but other than that.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I just hope you know who the father is. Lori stops.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you just said that.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean it in a bad way...

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I slept with Jacob one time. When I had to go to his house to pick up my dogs, thanks to you. Besides, I’m probably barren. You should worry about that. I have a lot of testosterone in me. (looking at stick) There. See? A single line. No grand-kids. Congratulations. Lori wraps the stick in toilet paper and puts it on top o the piled garbage. The garbage tips over and the stick shoots out. Marnie leans over it.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Lor? Lori comes back and leans over it. They both see a double line. It takes a second to sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the what? Lori grabs the box and pulls out a second stick.

dialogues.speaker: -- LATER
dialogues.text: Marnie and Lori look at two sticks with double lines.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the what??

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Maybe we should google it. Marnie pulls out her phone.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Google what?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, it could be a false positive.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: It doesn’t work that way. It’s not AIDS. I need to get a blood test.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: For AIDS?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: For this, Mom! Are you here?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I’m pregnant. And I’m too old to have an abortion. This is real. Lori hugs her knees and buries her head. Marnie goes to

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Lor. Don’t be sad. Lori lifts her head.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I’m not. 94. her. Lori tries to hide her smile but she can’t. She smiles wi and wider. Marnie quickly gets just as happy.  112 113 95. INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE -- LATER 112 Marnie watches Lori bounce her legs while a NURSE (50s) t her blood.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: My daughter was a surprise. Lori smiles, then winces from the needle. INT. Lori Lori Lori Lori LORI’S CAR -- LATER 113 drives with Marnie in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I should sell my house. Get something bigger with carpets... How am I gonna tell Jacob? starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t believe Dad’s not around.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I’m around. turns to her mother and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. 's cell phone rings. She answers on speaker.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, hon, it’s Anna in Dr. Segal’s office. It’s negative.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: What about all the tests I took?  96.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know, but we tested your blood and urine and you’re not pregnant. I’m sorry, hon. Marnie takes out her phone, looking online.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Okay, thanks for calling. Lori hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: It says here that a false positive could be certain types of stomach tumors. Do you feel sick? Lori looks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Yes. I feel very sick. 114 INT. LORI’S HOUSE -- LATER 114 Lori storms into the house, heading straight for the bathroom. Marnie follows.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Maybe you could ask the doctor to test the blood for other stuff? Like AIDS.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I don’t have AIDS.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I said like AIDS. Lori picks up the bag of sticks and looks.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I don’t get it, it says if you have two lines, that means you’re ovu...lating.... (then) What the fuck?? She holds the bag out to Marnie.  97.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? I’ve been peeing on ovulation sticks? Marnie looks at the bag.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You bought ovulation sticks? Marnie suddenly cracks up laughing.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This isn’t funny, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, come on...

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Do you understand the roller- coaster you put me on? I went from pregnant to stomach tumors to... ovulating in three hours.... Lori suddenly bursts into laughter. Marnie cracks up more The two of them roll around on the bathroom floor togethe hysterically laughing. Until, Lori stops. And she’s cryin

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Lor, I wasn’t laughing at you. Lori can’t stop crying. Marnie wraps her arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But this is a good thing. You didn’t plan it.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I know. (then) I was just relieved to have that decision made for me. Lori sobs in her mother’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh God, I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: For the way I am.  98.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I love you the way you are.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I just miss him so much.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe he’s not the one for you...

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Not Jacob. Dad. I miss Dad. I miss my dad.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I know and it’s hard to look at you sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Cause half the room is missing. (then) And we're both alone. Marnie pulls her in as tight as she can.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: We’re not alone. Lori wipes away a few tears, leaning into her mother.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: See, this is what happens when you follow the black sheep across the country. Marnie rests her head on Lori’s head.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Well, if you're a black sheep, I’m a black sheep. Marnie rocks her back on forth on the bathroom floor. Lor slowly stops crying.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: You beat up Greg’s dad.  99. INT. LORI’S BEDROOM -- NIGHT 115 Marnie lies awake, staring up at the ceiling fan, Lori as next to her. The fan cools the room with a mechanical breeze. Marnie stares at the blades spinning around and around and around and around and -- She gasps, sitting straight up. INT. MARNIE’S APARTMENT -- LATER 116 Marnie searches her closet. Then pulls out a TUPPERWARE b and sets it on the bed. She opens the lid. It’s full of photos, memories, Joe’s old shirts. She slides things asi Looking for something. Until... her eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie walks down the hall carrying something in a plasti bag. She makes her way straight toward the old woman's ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And up to the old woman’s bed. The woman turns her eyes t Marnie, mouth agape, breathing.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: It’s me. The woman’s hand raises into the air and points. Marnie reaches into her plastic bag and pulls out a ROTARY PHONE She pulls the plug out of the hospital phone and inserts into the rotary phone. She holds it up, then lifts the receiver to her ear. The old woman’s finger guides throug the air and lands in a slot - 7. The old woman turns her finger and begins to dial. Marnie’s eyes widen - 5. The woman moves her hand in the same circular motion - 4.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, shoot, I think you need to dial a nine first, let me, darn it... Marnie hangs up, tsks at herself and quickly dials a 9. T holds it out again. The woman uses all of her energy to d again -7-5-4-4-1- 7-7 - and stops. Marnie waits, phone to her ear. And it rings. Now Marnie’s breathing fills the room. It rings again and  120 121 122 100.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello? Marnie stops, can’t speak.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old lady is surrounded in stuffed animals. Marnie sit next to her, holding her hand, when a MAN (40s) enters th room. Marnie stands to greet him. He hugs Marnie, grateful, then quickly moves to the hospi bed. He leans over the old woman.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Mom? The old woman looks up at him. Her eyes fill with happy tears. His do the same.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s me, Mom. I’m here. He brushes the hair off her face, kissing her hands. Marn watches, overwhelmed. The same tears fill her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie watches as her fixed Toyota is lowered to the grou INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- LATER 121 Marnie drives up the Pacific Coast Highway, windows down, perfect weather, the sun glistening on the ocean. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- LATER 122 Marnie parks near the sand and opens the glove compartmen Inside, a SEALED URN. Marnie takes it out.  123 124 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie walks across the sand, holding the urn. As she get closer to the water, she kicks off her shoes. She steps out into the ocean, her pants getting wet up to knees. It’s colder than the Atlantic. She unseals the urn. And talks to the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Joey, I don’t know if this is what you want. But it’s all I can do. She takes the ashes and begins to sprinkle them. The wave move around her, sending his spirit out to sea. It’s over too quickly.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hold it right there. A VOICE echoes across the beach. Marnie turns back to see POLICE CAR in the sand. A MALIBU COP (40s) is making his to her. It’s nobody she knows.

dialogues.speaker: MALIBU COP
dialogues.text: What is that you’re doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Uh... none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: MALIBU COP
dialogues.text: Ma’am, this is a private beach. It’s illegal to be doing what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: You've gotta be kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: MALIBU COP
dialogues.text: Can you step out of the water please?

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: I am a resident of greater Los Angeles. And if you want me to get out of this ocean, you're just gonna have to come in here and drag me the hell out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie is pushed into a seat, soaking wet.  125 126 127 102.

dialogues.speaker: MALIBU COP
dialogues.text: Think about who your one phone call is. He walks out, soaking wet, and shuts the doors on her. Sh sits and thinks about who her phone call will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie comes down the jail steps, looks up, and stops to Zipper standing by his motorcycle, smiling. She looks exhausted, but can’t help but smile when she sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marnie rides on the back of Zipper’s bike, her arms wrapp around his waist. The sun is setting and simply beautiful

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zipper pulls his motorcycle up to Marnie’s Toyota, still parked in the lot. She steps off the bike. He cuts the engine. They look at each other. The ocean sounds nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Do you ever listen to Beyonce?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: She has this song called “I Was Here”, have you heard it?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: It goes... “I wanna leave my footprints on the sands of time, know there was something that I left behind. When I leave this world, I’ll leave no regrets, to leave something to remember, so they won’t forget”.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: That sounds like a good one.  128 103.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Did you bail me out because you had to as an officer of the law?

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: No, that’s actually the opposite of what I usually do. (then) I bailed you out as a friend. She smiles. Then reaches out and takes hold of his hand. His thumb gently rubs hers. She interlocks fingers. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Do you want to go to an action movie sometime? He looks up at her. A smile spreads across his tan face.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPER
dialogues.text: Definitely. They look at each other. And suddenly, slowly, they lean He kisses her on the mouth, gently, but with fire behind They slowly pull away. Their hands slide apart. Marnie turns away, walking back to her car, smiling the whole wa He watches her go, then “kick-starts” his bike and rides INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- MOMENTS LATER 128 Marnie climbs into the driver’s seat and shuts the door. Taking a moment to realize her iPhone is on the console w she left it. She picks it up to see:

dialogues.speaker: LORI VOICEMAIL, (3)
dialogues.text: Marnie gasps, surprised. She quickly listens, in order.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom, where are you? You left in the middle of the night and I got worried. Are you okay? Call me back when you get this. Marnie beams brighter than we’ve ever seen her. She hits next voicemail.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, it's me, I hope you're not mad at me. Maybe just text me and let me know that you got this. Okay, love you.  104. Marnie’s eyes well with happy tears. She hits the next voicemail.

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm officially worried. Where are you? Call me. This is weird. This is your daughter. She hits another voicemail. Jillian’s voice comes on.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Marnie. It's Jillian. I was wondering if you could watch Tehya for me today... Marnie’s eyes shoot open. JILLIAN (0.S.) (CONT’D) The nanny is sick and Dani and I have this thing at seven.... Marnie looks at the clock. JILLIAN (0.S.) (CONT’D) So if you could be here by then... Turns the ignition. And takes off. Marnie drops her phone. INT. JILLIAN’S HOUSE -- LATER/NIGHT 129 129 Jillian opens the door to see Marnie panting, out of brea

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: You are a lifesaver. Jillian hugs Marnie, then shouts into the house.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're leaving! (then, to Tehya) Grandma Marnie is here! Dani! Little Tehya comes running up to Marnie. She bends down a Tehya’s tiny arms wrap around her neck. It’s the greatest feeling in the world.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you mind putting her to bed? Tehya runs up the stairs to her room. Marnie follows her.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Sure.  130

dialogues.speaker: 'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Tehya kicks around some toys, while Marnie situates herse in a nearby rocking chair.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: What should we do? You want me to tell you a story?

dialogues.speaker: TEHYA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Tehya hands Marnie a book.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I know this. I used to read it to my Lori. Tehya peels open the pages and Marnie begins to read. Tehya lies

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading) “The Skin Horse had lived longer in the nursery than any of the others. He was so old that his brown coat was bald in patches and showed the seams underneath, and most of the hairs in his tail had been pulled out to string bead necklaces. He was wise, for he had seen a long succession of mechanical toys arrive to boast and swagger, and by- and-by break their mainsprings and pass away, and he knew that they were only toys, and would never turn into anything else. For nursery magic is very strange and wonderful, and only those playthings that are old and wise and experienced like the Skin Horse understand all about it. down in her lap. Marnie clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘What is REAL?’ asked the Velveteen Rabbit one day... ‘Does it mean having things that buzz inside you and a stick-out handle?’ ‘Real isn't how you are made,' said the Skin Horse. ‘It's a thing that happens to you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When a child loves you for a long, long time, not just to play with, but REALLY loves you, then you become Real.' 'Does it hurt?' asked the Rabbit. 'Sometimes,' said the Skin Horse, for he was always truthful. ‘When you are Real you don't mind being hurt.' 'Does it happen all at once, like being wound up,' he asked, ‘or bit by bit?' 'It doesn't happen all at once,' said the Skin Horse. 'You become. It takes a long time. That's why it doesn't happen often to people who break easily, or have sharp edges, or who have to be carefully kept. She has trouble reading, keeping the tears from her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Generally, by the time you are Real, most of your hair has been loved off, and your eyes drop out and you get loose in the joints and very shabby. But these things don't matter at all, because once you are Real you can't be ugly, except to people who don't understand.” She stops.

dialogues.speaker: TEHYA
dialogues.text: More. She blinks the tears away, then turns to the girl. And smiles. Opening up the book again.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: More.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is shining. Another blue-sky day. Marnie’s Toyota makes its way down a tree-lined street. INT. MARNIE’S TOYOTA -- CONTINUOUS 131 Marnie holds her cell phone in her hand, her daughter’s picture on the home screen. She looks at the phone, waiting for it to get service.  107. NO SERVICE. ONE BAR. TWO BARS. FULL BARS. Marnie pulls up her list of FAVORITES: LORI and ZIPPER. S chooses Lori. The phone rings and rings and then:

dialogues.speaker: LORI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Lori, leave a message. Marnie waits for the BEEP. Takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE
dialogues.text: Anyway... I just wanted to see what you were up to and how your date went last night... or whatever you said to call it... I don’t know how much longer I’m gonna have service.... As Marnie continues, CREDITS BEGIN TO ROLL OVER HER.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cause I’m headed to Topanga to see my friend with the chickens, and also that new Jason Statham movie about the guy who stops time. It looks fabulous. And then I told Jillian that I'd baby-sit Tehya tomorrow, so I’1l be in the neighborhood if you want me to drop off any bagels....

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO
dialogues.text: OVER BLACK: Credits continue. And so does Marnie.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (OVER BLACK)
dialogues.text: «+. Or read to me what you’re working on or whatever... Cause I was thinking that maybe next weekend I might take a ride out to the desert maybe. Not sure if I’m gonna stay overnight, but.... It’s just something I’ve been thinking about.... Seeing the desert.... And, you know, it’s right there, so.... Anyway, call me. Love you. Marnie thinks she’s hung up. But we still hear her. She starts humming to herself. Then, finally realizes.

dialogues.speaker: MARNIE, (OVER BLACK)
dialogues.text: Ooh. Marnie hangs up.
